Graphical abstract Nano-Au dispersed on nanocrystalline CeO2-ZrO2 support exhibits a higher catalytic efficiency in the solvent-free oxidative coupling of benzylamine, which is attributed to catalytically favorable properties of nano-Au and the CeO2-ZrO2 support. Designing Au nanocatalysts supported on nanosized metal oxides has drawn much attention due to remarkable nanoscale influenced metal-support interactions and their favorable role in heterogeneous catalysis. This work reports development of Au nanocatalysts dispersed on nanosized CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports for solvent- and base-free oxidative coupling of benzylamines into N-benzylbenzaldimines using O2 as a green oxidant. The physicochemical characterization of nanocatalysts has been undertaken using HRTEM, UV–vis DRS, XRD, Raman, BET, TG-DTA, AAS, and XPS techniques. HRTEM images reveal the formation of nanosized CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports with an average diameter of ∼10 and 7nm, respectively. HRTEM images also indicated that Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst has smaller Au nanoparticles (∼2.1nm) compared with that of Au/CeO2 catalyst (∼3.7nm). Raman and XPS studies showed that the addition of ZrO2 to CeO2 leads to abundant oxygen vacancies and higher concentration of Ce3+, respectively. The Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited a higher efficiency in benzylamine conversion (∼95%) followed by Au/CeO2 (∼78%), CeO2-ZrO2 (∼51%), and CeO2 (∼39%). The Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst was also found to effective for oxidative coupling of various benzylamines, and moderate to good product yields were obtained. The presence of smaller Au particles (2.1nm) and improved surface-defect properties of nanoscale CeO2-ZrO2 support are found to be key factors for high performance of Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. Additionally, the reaction temperature is one of the important factors for the performance of catalysts. Remarkably, ∼99.6–99.9% selectivity for N-benzylbenzaldimines was found in the amine oxidation, which highlights the significance of present work in the selective oxidation catalysis. Keywords Nano-gold Nanoscale ceria Zirconium Characterization Eco-friendly benzylamine oxidation 1 Introduction Catalysis using supported gold nanoparticles (Au NPs) is currently one of the most attractive research areas due to its wide significance in the chemical industry [1,2]. Indeed, bulk gold had long been considered as catalytically ‘inactive’ metal [3]. However, the pioneering discoveries of Haruta and Hutchings have been demonstrated that smaller sized gold nanoparticles dispersed on suitable metal oxides exhibit a remarkable catalytic performance in the oxidation of carbon monoxide and hydrochlorination of ethyne, respectively [3,4]. Consequently, the Au nanocatalysts have been widely used in many reactions of both environmental and industrial importance, such as CO oxidation, oxidation of alcohols, chemoselective hydrogenation, CC and CN coupling reactions, H2O2 production, water–gas-shift reaction, combustion of volatile organic compounds and oxidation of olefins [5–15]. In particular, the oxidative coupling of benzylamines into N-benzylbenzaldimines using nano-Au catalysts has received tremendous attention due to the many useful applications of imines [16–18]. For example, N-benzylbenzaldimines are important building blocks for the synthesis of dyes, polymers, agrochemicals, fine chemicals, anti-inflammatory and anti-cancer agents [19,20]. Owing to the CN double bond, N-benzylbenzaldimines can also be used in a number of transformations, such as hydrogenation, cycloaddition, and nucleophilic addition reactions. Stoichiometric amounts of chromate, permanganate, 2-iodoxybenzoic acid, and N-tert-butylphenylsulfinimidoyl-chloride are typically used oxidants for the oxidation of organic compounds [21,22]. However, the use of stoichiometric (hazardous) oxidants is unfavorable from the perspective of sustainable chemical industry. On the other hand, the catalytic efficiency of several Au catalysts has been tested for the oxidation of benzylamines using molecular oxygen (O2) as the oxidant [17,23–25]. O2 is an abundant and eco-friendly oxidant that generates only water as the by-product in the benzylamine oxidation, hence O2 is an efficient alternative to stoichiometric (hazardous) oxidants [18]. However, the major limitations in the above Au-catalyzed benzylamine oxidation reactions is the use of harmful organic solvents and bases, which generates large amounts of toxic chemical waste and requires a tedious workup procedure for separating the Au catalysts from the reaction mixture as well as for analyzing the reaction products. Therefore, developing greener and more efficient methodologies that can be performed under solvent- and base-free conditions using O2 as the oxidant are highly desirable toward a sustainable organic chemistry. It is now a well-known fact that the nature of metal oxide supports plays a pivotal role in modifying the structure-activity properties of nano-Au catalysts [26]. The metal oxides can be classified into reducible or active supports, such as TiO2, CeO2, Fe2O3, and MnO2, and inert supports, such as SiO2, MgO, and Al2O3. It has been reported that Au nanoparticles supported on reducible metal oxides exhibit a higher catalytic performance compared with that of Au nanoparticles supported on inert metal oxides [27,28]. The reason is that reducible metal oxides provide active sites for the adsorption of oxygen, generating active oxygen species for the oxidation reactions [29–31]. Cerium oxide (CeO2) is one of the widely used active supports for the Au nanoparticle-catalyzed reactions [27,31–34]. This significance has been aroused due to unique properties of CeO2, such as abundant oxygen vacancies and remarkable redox properties (Ce3+ ↔Ce4+). In addition, the particle size of CeO2 plays a key role in enhancing the efficiency of Au catalysts. It has been shown that nano-CeO2 supported Au catalyst exhibits better activity compared with that of bulk CeO2 supported Au catalyst in the oxidation of carbon monoxide and oxidation of alcohols [32,34]. It is therefore believed that by enhancing the textural (e.g., surface area) and redox properties of ceria, the catalytic efficiency of Au catalysts can be improved. The doping of metal ions (e.g., Zr4+) into the CeO2 is one of the promising ways to modify its physicochemical properties [7,35–37]. Doped ceria materials exhibit smaller particle size, higher specific surface area, and more number of oxygen vacancies compared with bare ceria, which is attributed to the co-operation effect of the cerium and dopant. Particularly, oxygen vacancies play a favorable role in the adsorption and activation of gaseous phase oxygen in order to interact with the reactant molecules in the oxidation reactions [38,39]. The present study has been undertaken against the above background. Nanoscale CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 (Ce/Zr=1/1) supports were synthesized using a modified co-precipitation method. Au nanoparticles are dispersed onto the nanoscale CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports using a deposition–precipitation method. The physicochemical properties of the nanocatalysts were systematically analyzed using X-ray diffraction (XRD), thermogravimetric-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA), BET surface area, atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (UV–vis DRS), and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) techniques. The catalytic efficiency of the nanocatalysts was studied for the oxidative coupling of various benzylamines. The catalytic experiments have been conducted under solvent- and base-free conditions using O2, a greener and more efficient methodology toward a sustainable chemistry. To the best of our knowledge, this is first report on the catalytic performance of Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts for the solvent- and base-free oxidative coupling of benyzlamines using molecular oxygen. Great efforts have been made to correlate the catalytic activity results with the characterization studies. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Nanoscale 50% Zr-doped CeO2 was synthesized using a modified co-precipitation method from ultra-high dilute aqueous solutions, which is crucial for synthesizing nanoscale CeO2-based metal oxides [40,41]. The employed precursors are NH4Ce(NO3)4·6H2O (Aldrich, AR grade), ZrO(NO3)2·xH2O (Fluka, AR grade). Extremely dilute aq. NH3 solution (2.5 v/v%) was used as the precipitating agent. In a typical procedure, the required amounts of metal precursors are dissolved in Milli-Q water under mild stirring conditions. The precipitant was added slowly to the above mixture solution over a period of 1h until the pH of the solution reached to ∼8.5. The obtained precipitates were decanted, filtered off, washed with Milli-Q water, and oven dried at 393K for 12h. The sample was then calcined at 773K for 5h in air at a heating rate of 5K/min. Nanoscale CeO2 support was also synthesized using the same preparation method. Homogeneous deposition precipitation method was used to synthesize 1wt.% Au catalysts. In brief, to prepare the Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst the adequate amounts of HAuCl4·4H2O (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%) and urea (urea:Au=100 mole ratio) are dissolved in Milli-Q water and the solution was then heated to 343K. The required amount of CeO2-ZrO2 support was added to the Au solution and the stirring was continued for 12h at the same temperature. The solution was then cooled to room temperature, filtered off, and washed with Milli-Q water until no traces of chloride ions were detected by AgNO3 test. Finally, the sample was oven dried at 373K for 12h and calcined in air at 573K for 4h (1K/min). The Au/CeO2 catalyst was also synthesized by adopting the same method. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder XRD analysis was performed using a Rigaku diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (0.15418nm) and a scintillation counter detector. Scherrer equation and standard cubic indexation method were used to determine the average crystallite size of CeO2 and its lattice parameter in the synthesized catalysts, respectively. The TG-DTA analysis was carried out on a Mettler Toledo TG-SDTA instrument. The samples were heated from ambient temperature to 1073K with a heating rate of 5K min−1 under the flow of N2. HRTEM studies were made on a JEOL JEM-2100F instrument equipped with a slow-scan CCD camera and an accelerating voltage of the electron beam 80kV. The preparation of samples involves sonication in acetone for 10min, followed by deposition of a drop on the copper grid supporting a perforated carbon film and allowed to dry. The Au content of the catalysts was estimated using the AAS technique. For this, Spectra AA-220 spectrophotometer at a wavelength of 242.8nm was used. The UV–vis DRS measurements were performed over the wavelength range of λ =200–750nm using a GBS–Cintra 10e UV–vis NIR spectrophotometer with an integration sphere diffuse reflectance attachment. Sample was diluted in a KBr matrix by pelletization. N2-adsorption/desorption isotherms of the catalysts were obtained on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument at liquid N2 temperature (77.25K). Prior to analysis, the samples were degassed at 423K for 16h. XPS studies were conducted using a Thermo K-5 Alpha XPS instrument with Al Kα radiation (photon energy=1486.6eV) at a pass energy of 50eV. The core level binding energies (BEs) were charge corrected with respect to carbon (C 1s) peak at 284.8eV. Raman analysis was performed using PerkinElmer-Raman Station 400F (785nm laser, spot size of 100mm) spectrometer equipped with a liquid N2 cooled charge coupled device detector and a confocal microscope. The samples were excited with 350mW near infrared 785nm laser with the diameter of the analyzed spot being ∼1μm. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The oxidation of benzylamines was performed using O2 as the oxidant under solvent-free conditions. Typically, 0.1g of catalyst and 2mmol of benzylamine were taken into a 10mL round bottom flask. The reaction mixture was then heated to the required temperature. O2 was bubbled at a rate of 20mL/min under 800rpm stirring conditions. After the reaction, the liquid products and the catalyst were separated by centrifugation. The products were confirmed by GC–MS equipped with a DB-5 capillary column. All the reaction samples were analysed by GC equipped with a BP-20 (wax) capillary column fitted with a FID detector. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization studies The HRTEM studies have been carried out to get an overview on the nature of the CeO2, CeO2-ZrO2 and Au particles, as well to estimate their particle size. Fig. 1 shows HRTEM images of CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports. As can be noted from Fig. 1, the supports are highly crystalline materials in the nanoscale range. The lattice fringes for both supports are clearly visible with an estimated d-spacing of 0.31nm, which is attributed to (111) plane of the cerium oxide [18]. It was found that the CeO2-ZrO2 support exhibits smaller sized particles (∼7±2nm) compared with that of CeO2 (∼10±2nm). This observation indicates the beneficial role of Zr-dopant in the reduction of particle size of cerium oxide. Fig. 2 shows HRTEM images of Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 samples. A careful observation of Fig. 2 reveals that Au/CeO2 sample contains different sized Au particles with an average diameter of 3.7±0.5nm. On the other hand, smaller sized Au particles (∼2.1±0.5nm) were found for Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst, which is due to the existence of strong interaction between the Au and CeO2-ZrO2 support (Fig. 2 and Fig. S1 of the Supplementary material). Lattice fringes with a d-spacing of 0.31nm corresponding to CeO2 (111) plane can also be clearly observed in all gold catalysts. UV–vis DRS analysis has been performed to elucidate the presence of Au in the synthesized catalysts (Fig. S2 of the Supplementary material). It was found that both Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts display a broad surface plasmon resonance (SPR) band centred at ∼580nm. This band is the characteristic of Au nanoparticles, indicating the presence of nano-Au in the synthesized catalysts, in line with the HRTEM studies (Fig. 2) [42]. The appearance of SPR band is dependent on various parameters, which includes Au particle size, its shape, Au amount, and dielectric function of the surrounding environment [31,43,44]. It is interesting to note that Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst exhibits a higher intensity SPR band compared with that of Au/CeO2 catalyst. This observation indicates the presence of higher amount of Au onto the CeO2-ZrO2 support, in line with the AAS analysis (Table 1 ). The powder XRD patterns of nanoscale CeO2, CeO2-ZrO2, Au/CeO2, and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 samples are shown in Fig. 3 . All the catalysts exhibit characteristic fluorite cubic structured CeO2 patterns at 2 theta values of 28.65, 33.03, 47.46, 56.31, 59.06, 69.41, 76.66, and 79.03° [45–49]. Interestingly, the XRD peaks related to ZrO2 phases are not found for CeO2-ZrO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts. On the other hand, the XRD peaks of pristine CeO2 are shifted considerably toward higher angles after the addition of Zr dopant. The estimated lower lattice parameter of CeO2-ZrO2 (0.5320nm) compared with that of CeO2 (0.5411nm) also evidenced this observation (Table 1). The ionic radius of Zr4+ dopant (0.084nm) is much smaller compared with that of Ce4+ (0.097nm), hence, a peak shifting and decrease in the lattice parameter of ceria can be observed after doping the Zr into the CeO2 lattice (Fig. 3 and Table 1). The average crystallite size of the samples was estimated using Scherrer equation (Table 1). The crystallite size of the supports was found to be in the nanoscale range: Zr-doped CeO2 has smaller crystallite size (∼4.6nm) compared with that of bare CeO2 (∼8.7). The specific surface area of CeO2 was significantly increased from 42 to 82m2/g after the addition of Zr (Table 1). This observation indicates the existence of strong interaction between the Zr-dopant and Ce in the Ce1-x Zr x O2, which ultimately leads to strong resistance ability against higher thermal treatments in line with the crystallite size of the samples (Table 1). Interestingly, no considerable variation in the crystallite size and surface area of the supports was observed after the addition of Au (Table 1). In this study, no Au XRD peaks were noticed for Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts (Fig. 3). This observation is most probably due to low Au loading and/or due to high dispersion of Au onto the surface of supports [50]. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the samples are shown in Fig. 4 . Except Au/CeO2, all samples exhibit type IV isotherm with H1-type hysteresis, which indicates mesoporosity of the material [51]. In contrast, the Au/CeO2 catalyst showed H2-type isotherm, in which the distribution of pore size and shape is not well defined. The pore size of CeO2, Au/CeO2, CeO2-ZrO2, and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 samples was found to be ∼9.818, 3.479, 6.734, and 5.989nm, respectively. As well, the obtained pore volumes are ∼0.113, 0.066, 0.434, and 0.396cm3 g−1 for CeO2, Au/CeO2, CeO2-ZrO2, and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 samples, respectively. The TG-DTA analysis of Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 samples shows a major weight loss peak in the range of 373–423K, which reveals desorption of hydroxyl species from the catalyst surface (Fig. S3 of the Supplementary material). In addition, a sharp weight loss peak was found for Au/CeO2 sample at around 823–923K, which is attributed to desorption of carbonate species from the catalyst surface. The appearance of second weight loss peak is almost negligible for Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. The estimated Au amounts from the AAS analysis were found to be ∼0.87 and 0.95% for Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 samples, respectively (Table 1). Raman spectroscopy is an efficient technique to understand the structural features and surface-defects of CeO2 based materials. Fig. 5 shows Raman spectra of nanoscale CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports. A prominent Raman peak was found at around 464–470cm−1 for both supports, which indicates F2g vibration model of octahedral local symmetry around CeO2 lattice [32,52]. Appearance of this band confirms the fluorite cubic structured ceria, in line with the XRD studies (Fig. 3). In addition, the CeO2-ZrO2 support exhibits a Raman band at around 307cm−1, which is attributed to the displacement of oxygen atoms from their ideal fluorite lattice positions [53]. Another broad Raman band was observed at ∼600cm−1 for CeO2-ZrO2 support, which reveals the presence of oxygen vacancies (Ov) [54,55]. Owing to difference in the ionic radii of Ce4+-host and Zr4+-dopant, a distortion in the oxygen sublattice of ceria may be possible after the addition of Zr, leading to displacement of oxygen atoms form their positions, hence formation of oxygen vacancies in the CeO2-ZrO2 support. XPS analysis has been performed to understand the electronic properties of the elements present in the synthesized catalysts. Fig. 6 shows Au 4f XPS spectra of Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts. Both catalysts exhibit two major peaks at around ∼83.8 and 87.5eV, corresponding to Au 4f7/2 and Au 4f5/2 transitions, respectively [7]. Appearance of these peaks indicates the presence of metallic Au in the synthesized Au catalysts. Fig. 7 shows Ce 3d XPS spectra of CeO2, CeO2-ZrO2, Au/CeO2, and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 7, the Ce 3d spectra can be labeled as u and v, corresponding to the 3d3/2 and 3d5/2 contributions, respectively [56–58]. Peaks denoted by u/ and v/ indicate the Ce3+ ions, while those marked by v, u, v//, u//, v/// and u/// reveal the presence of Ce4+ ions in the synthesized samples. It is therefore clear that all samples contain both Ce4+ and Ce3+ ions, indicating the redox nature of the samples. The concentration of Ce3+ in the samples was estimated from the ratio of integrated Ce3+ peaks (u/ and v/) to the total Ce as follows Concentration of Ce 3+ ( % ) = [ I ( Ce 3+ ) ] [ I ( Ce 3+ ) +I ( Ce 4+ ) ] × 100 The obtained results are shown in Fig. 8 . It was found that CeO2-ZrO2 sample exhibits large amounts of Ce3+ ions compared to CeO2. The XRD studies revealed that the incorporation of Zr into the CeO2 lattice leads to a lattice contraction due to the smaller size of guest Zr4+ (0.084nm) compared with that of Ce4+ (0.097nm) (Fig. 3 and Table 1). As a result, the transformation of Ce4+ (0.097nm) to Ce3+ (0.114nm) occurs to compensate the lattice contraction, hence higher concentration of Ce3+ ions in the CeO2-ZrO2 sample [59,60]. Interestingly, the addition of gold to CeO2 supports leads to an enhancement in the concentration of Ce3+ ions. This observation indicates that the Au addition has a favorable effect on the redox properties of CeO2 supports. Among those, the Au/CeO2-ZrO2 sample exhibits more number of Ce3+ ions, indicating the existence of strong interactions between the Au and the CeO2-ZrO2 support [61–63]. The O 1s spectra of the catalysts show two bands, which reveal the existence of different oxygen species in the synthesized samples (Fig. S4 of the Supplementary material). The observed band at around 529–530eV indicates the lattice oxygen, whereas the peak in the region of 531–533eV reveals the adsorbed hydroxyl and carbonate species [64]. The obtained Zr 3d XPS spectra show two major bands at around 184.8 (3d3/2) and 181.9eV (3d5/2), which indicate the presence of Zr4+ ions in the synthesised catalysts (Fig. S5 of the Supplementary material). 3.2 Catalytic activity studies The catalytic performance of Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 nanocatalysts, along with nanoscale CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports was investigated for oxidative coupling of benzylamine and the results are presented in Table 2 . The reaction was performed at 403K for 6h with O2 as a green oxidant under solvent- and base-free conditions. It was found that the nanoscale CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports exhibit reasonable catalytic efficiency in the benzylamine oxidation with ∼39 and 51% amine conversions, respectively. This observation indicates that the addition of Zr to CeO2 has shown a significant effect in improving the benzylamine conversion. Remarkably, higher conversions of benzylamine were found for the Au catalysts (Table 2), which indicate the catalytic role of Au nanoparticles in the oxidation of benzylamine. The achieved benzylamine conversions for Au/CeO2 and Au/CeO2-ZrO2 nanocatalysts were ∼78 and 95%, respectively. It was clear that Au/CeO2-ZrO2 nanocatalyst exhibits a higher efficiency in the oxidation of benzylamine compared with that of Au/CeO2 nanocatalyst. The estimated TOF values also evidence higher catalytic performance of Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst compared to all tested catalysts (Table 2). Interestingly, almost ∼99.5% selectivity toward N-benzylbenzaldimine product was found for all catalysts (Table 2). This result highlights the significance of present work in the selective oxidation reactions. As shown in Scheme 1 , the Au catalyst initiates the oxidation of benzylamine through the formation of coordination with the non-bonded electron pair of nitrogen of amine, leading to the formation of imine intermediate [65–68]. The further oxidative dehydrogenation of imine intermediate yields the benzonitrile product. In contrast, the condensation between the imine intermediate and benzylamine gives the N-benzylbenzaldimine product. It is therefore obvious from Table 2 that nanoscale ceria based supports and corresponding Au nanocatalysts selectively favor the formation of N-benzylbenzaldimine product in the aerobic oxidation of benzylamine under solvent-free conditions. The performance of Au nanocatalysts can be attributed to several factors, such as the properties of support, the size of Au particles, and the interaction between the Au and support [7,17,32]. It has been shown that nanosized ceria plays a beneficial role in the Au-catalyzed oxidation reactions, such as CO oxidation and oxidation of alcohols compared with the bulk ceria [34,69]. This is due to the combined catalytically favorable properties of Au nanoparticles and nanosized ceria supports, which can ultimately lead to enhanced catalytic efficiency of nanoscale Au/CeO2 catalysts. In the present study, both CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports are found to be in nanoscale range (Fig. 1 and Table 1). As a result, reasonable amine conversions were found for these supports (Table 2). Among those, the CeO2-ZrO2 support shows much enhanced properties, such as smaller particle size, higher BET surface area, large amounts of oxygen vacancies and higher numbers of Ce3+ ions compared with that of pure CeO2 (Table 1, Figs. 1, 5 and 8). Hence, a strong interaction between the Au and CeO2-ZrO2 support can be expected, which could lead to improved catalytic performance of nanostructured Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. As expected, the Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst exhibits smaller Au nanoparticles, higher Au amount, and large amounts of Ce3+ ions compared with that of Au/CeO2 catalyst (Table 1 and Fig. 8). Therefore, the Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst showed a higher catalytic performance in the benzylamine oxidation (Table 2). In order to understand the effect of temperature on benzylamine conversion and product selectivity, the reaction was performed at different temperature intervals in the range of 353–413K using Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst (Fig. 9 ). The conversion of benzylamine was found to be 11% at 353K. Afterwards, the conversion of benzylamine increases with increasing the temperature: approximately 23, 47, 65, 82, 95, and 99% of benzylamine conversions were achieved at 363, 373, 383, 393, 403, and 413K of reaction temperatures, respectively. In contrast, the benzylamine conversion was found to be very low (∼3%) at room temperature. This observation indicates that the reaction temperature plays a pivotal role on the performance of the catalysts for the oxidation of benzylamine. Interestingly, there was no significant variation in the products selectivity with the temperature. The selectivity of N-benzylbenzaldimine and benzonitrile products was found to ∼99.6–99.9 and 0.4–0.1%, respectively, at all reaction temperatures. Subsequently, time-dependent experiments were carried out for the oxidation of benzylamine using Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst at 413K (Fig. 10 ). As can be noted from Fig. 10, the conversion of benzylamine was considerably increased with increasing the reaction time. The achieved benzylamine conversions are ∼36, 51, 63, 77, 87, 99, and 99% for 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7h of reaction times, respectively. This observation suggests that 6h is the optimum reaction time for achieving maximum benzylamine conversion when using Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. On the other hand, no considerable variation in the N-benzylbenzaldimine product selectivity (∼99.6–99.9%) was found with the reaction time. The obtained results clearly indicate that the selectivity of N-benzylbenzaldimine product in the benzylamine oxidation is independent of the reaction temperature and time when using Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. The applicability of Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst was also studied for the solvent-free oxidation of various substituted benzylamines using molecular oxygen. The obtained results are presented in Table 3 . It was found that the Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst exhibits a significant catalytic efficiency in converting the substituted benzylamines into the corresponding N-benzylbenzaldimines as well. Nearly 96–99% of conversions were found for all substituted benzylamines with the Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. This observation indicated that the efficiency of Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst is independent on the nature of the substituents present on the phenyl ring of benzylamine [70]. On the other hand, the position of the substituents shows a huge effect in the amine conversion. For example, low amine conversion was found for ortho-methyl substituted benzylamine (86%) compared with para-methyl substituted benzylamine (98%) for 6h of reaction time. Similar results are also found in the case of meta- and para-methoxy substituted benzylamines. These results indicate that the reaction is sensitive toward the steric hindrance of the substituents. Despite the nature of the substituent and its position on the benzylamine, almost 99.6–99.8% selectivity toward the imine product was achieved with the Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. The oxidation of secondary benzylamines was also performed using the Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst with O2 as the oxidant under solvent- and base-free conditions (Table 4 ). It was obvious that the oxidation of secondary amine to yield the desired imine product only involves a single step (Fig. S6 of the Supplementary material). As can be noted from Table 4, the conversion of amine was found to be dependent on the group attached to N atom of the benzylamine. For example, low amine conversion was observed for N-phenylbenzylamine (78%), followed by 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline (89%) and dibenzylamine (95%). On the other hand, almost 100% imine selectivity was found, which is attributed to lack of hydrogen atom attached to N atom of the benzylamine to give the nitrile product. It is therefore suggested that Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst can be efficiently used for the oxidation of substituted benzylamines and secondary benzylamines under eco-friendly conditions. 4 Conclusions In summary, nanoscale CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 oxides are employed as efficient supports for developing promising Au nanocatalysts. The catalytic efficiency of these nanoscale supports and nano-Au catalysts are studied for oxidative coupling of benzylamines under eco-friendly reaction conditions. It was found that Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst exhibits a higher catalytic performance in oxidative coupling of benzylamine (∼95%) compared to Au/CeO2 (∼78%), CeO2-ZrO2 (∼51%), and CeO2 (∼39%) samples. The Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst can be also efficiently used for the oxidative coupling of various substituted benzylamines and secondary benzylamines, and moderate to good product yields are obtained. The high catalytic performance of Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst is attributed to the presence of smaller Au particles (2.1nm) and improved surface-defect properties of nanoscale CeO2-ZrO2 support. In addition the reaction temperature has been found to show a significant effect on the performance of Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst for the benzylamine oxidation. Almost 99.6–99.9% selectivity toward N-benzylbenzaldimines was found irrespective of the catalysts used and the reaction conditions employed. We strongly believe that the significance of this novel work, along with eco-friendly reaction conditions would provide tremendous opportunities for the advancement of the selective oxidation catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Designing Au nanocatalysts supported on nanosized metal oxides has drawn much attention due to remarkable nanoscale influenced metal-support interactions and their favorable role in heterogeneous catalysis. This work reports development of Au nanocatalysts dispersed on nanosized CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports for solvent- and base-free oxidative coupling of benzylamines into N-benzylbenzaldimines using O2 as a green oxidant. The physicochemical characterization of nanocatalysts has been undertaken using HRTEM, UV–vis DRS, XRD, Raman, BET, TG-DTA, AAS, and XPS techniques. HRTEM images reveal the formation of nanosized CeO2 and CeO2-ZrO2 supports with an average diameter of ∼10 and 7nm, respectively. HRTEM images also indicated that Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst has smaller Au nanoparticles (∼2.1nm) compared with that of Au/CeO2 catalyst (∼3.7nm). Raman and XPS studies showed that the addition of ZrO2 to CeO2 leads to abundant oxygen vacancies and higher concentration of Ce3+, respectively. The Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst exhibited a higher efficiency in benzylamine conversion (∼95%) followed by Au/CeO2 (∼78%), CeO2-ZrO2 (∼51%), and CeO2 (∼39%). The Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst was also found to effective for oxidative coupling of various benzylamines, and moderate to good product yields were obtained. The presence of smaller Au particles (2.1nm) and improved surface-defect properties of nanoscale CeO2-ZrO2 support are found to be key factors for high performance of Au/CeO2-ZrO2 catalyst. Additionally, the reaction temperature is one of the important factors for the performance of catalysts. Remarkably, ∼99.6–99.9% selectivity for N-benzylbenzaldimines was found in the amine oxidation, which highlights the significance of present work in the selective oxidation catalysis.
coredata.dc:title: Promising nanostructured gold/metal oxide catalysts for oxidative coupling of benzylamines under eco-friendly conditions
